newsitem.title: PHILIPPINES: Manila call money drops on borrowing rate cut.
newsitem.headline: Manila call money drops on borrowing rate cut.

text.p: * C Bank cuts o/night borrowing, raises term reverse repos

Manila overnight money dropped to an average of 11.3125 percent on Tuesday from 11.5625 following the 0.25 percentage-point cut in the Central Bank's overnight borrowing rate to 11.25 percent, dealers said.
Done rates were at a lower range of 11.5/11.28125 percent, with 32 lenders and 21 borrowers.
Volume fell to 13.64 billion pesos from 19.29 billion.
In the secondary market, there was no aggressive buying of bills after the Central Bank raised its reverse repo rates by 0.25 percentage-point each on its one, two and six months terms.
"Banks were confused by the Central Bank's moves," a trader said.
"They want to assess the situation first. But I guess the Central Bank just doesn't want rates to fall too fast and add fuel to the foreign exchange situation," another trader said.
In the past seven days, the Central Bank had raised its overnight borrowing rate twice to tame peso speculation on fears of capital flight from stock market sales.
